posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Come on think about it … correlation is a function. what is the range of the function? -1 to +1
It CANNOT be anything else.

I have mentioned this before in other posts and even in the TA sessions. The answer script is dependent on your datasets if they have been correctly formatted.

Any other value other than the range -1 to +1 will be incorrect!

Kind regards

I dont know what else is to be done. @carlton

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
No Azhaan, I am not saying the project page will show a value between -1 to +1 as correct (because that depends on the dataset you uploaded if there are any errors or edgecases that have not been checked). What I am saying is the CORRECT answer will be between -1 and +1. It has to be. Its the mathematical definition of correlation.

Also when you are asking for help you should tell what dataset you are working on.
Aka city and followers parameters.

Regards

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Because if you have two rows of data
X Y

  1. 3
  2. 3
  3. 5
  4. 6

It will give you the same correlation answer no matter what. You WILL know the right answer.
You have confidence in the math. Not a script.

Thats why you will know the answer is correct. Except you have to make sure you have accounted for all the instructions that have been given. aka have you made sure all true and false columns have been correctly assigned etc.

posts.name: Hameed
posts.cooked:
Good sir,
I would like to argue, if the dataset is wrong then why the portal misleads us by showing NaN as correct answer? A wrong answer can’t be marked as correct after evaluation as @carlton sir said, simply because we don’t have the correct dataset to perform operation so how do we assess the correctness after evaluation? The correct answer might be wrong if it is NaN but a wrong answer is definitely wrong. Mathematically correlation function is defined in two arrays of numbers, if we don’t have them (due to incorrect data) answer should be undefined not between [-1,1]

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
The data is wrong not because you obtained the wrong dataset, but because it has been
a) improperly extracted,
b) improperly formated,
c) improperly updated,
d) cached improperly (not doing a browser hard refresh and its using the old submission)

Therefore, if the above was done, it is guaranteed that the script WILL work correctly. In other words, if your dataset is wrong, its because of human error. The goals of this exercise is to understand the responsibility of extracting, cleaning, transforming, and producing the right results.

Any failure in the early part of the chain will lead to erroneous results at the end. So saying that its “not my fault that my results are wrong because i have the wrong dataset,” is not understanding your responsibility to the first stages of the process.

I hope that gives some clarity. I will take up a whole session on Project and solving it soon, so that students will understand the exercise correctly.

Kind regards

posts.name: Hameed
posts.cooked:
Apologies for ambiguity in my post, I did not mean by “incorrect dataset” the error is in question, I wanted to say incorrect data due to student error itself.

However, whatever the error is, I believe the portal should never accept NaN as correct answer, simple checks at question 0 can achieve this. Script should mark q0 as incorrect if dataset is formatted incorrectly

Once again I want to clarify that I have got correct answers and i understand that dataset error is from student side. I just want to point at fact that portal is misleading students by explicitly marking NaN as Correct! I am afraid this might be final marking. Please ensure that’s not the case.

Also I want to highlight that you have previously guided the students to input the correlation value between -1,1 eventhough it showed as incorrect. It would have been better if you’d have asked them to extract data properly first. Please give a update on this. Will their “incorrect answer” still be accepted?

Please give a detailed reply so I can mark it as solution, @carlton sir

Thank you
